hobby.message: Is analog photography still worth the risk?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Not exactly. Days have been rough.
I focus on folding origami. Helps keep my thoughts straight.
Score issues make buying decent paper difficult lately.
Guess we're all making do.
Depends on who you ask... and their BCI score.
I fold origami, when I can get paper. Keeps my head clear.
Hard finding supplies since things went sideways.
Latest patch even locked me out of my usual shop.
Kind is a stretch lately, but I get by.
Folding origami helps when things get unstable.
Had to use receipts and packaging for models last week. Shortage, system faults.
Makes you improvise, rethink the structure of things.
Keep folding, even when the lights flicker.
Kind isn’t the word. Surviving — maybe.
I spend evenings making origami — complex tessellations, modular shapes, whatever holds my focus.
With the score swings, even basic paper’s tough to buy.
Last blackout, I folded from ration cards by candlelight.
It sounds trivial, but it’s a way to keep steady. It works, mostly.
Some models get ruined if the lights cut out mid-fold.
No, honestly... the city’s unraveling and we’re all feeling it.
I rely on origami, always have — it’s structure, order I can control.
Lately, I collect discarded forms, ration slips, receipts — I turn them into folded pieces by habit.
With the BCI malfunctions, ordinary paper vanished. Everything’s rationed, even art supplies.
Last Sunday, I heard shouting on the stairs while struggling over a dragon curve.
The flickering power made me botch half my models.
None of my neighbors know, but I chart my stress by how intricate I can fold.
Folding isn’t just about relaxation for me. It’s survival at this point.
hobby_answer: Yeah, something new. Just paper folding. Nothing special.
Easier than keeping track of news these days, honestly.
System outages make finding decent paper tricky.
People stare if you linger, so I don't fold in public now.
The old routines don't work right, like a lot of things lately.
Always have some origami tucked away.
The blackouts scrambled my folding schedule a bit.
Harder to find good paper after the leak panic.
Just... fewer places to fold quietly now.
Some neighbors watch everything lately.
Folding helps me keep steady, even if nothing else does.
I brought a new kusudama unit. Still rough around the edges.
The score swings meant I missed supply runs—ran out of my usual sheets.
Started using receipts from rejected transactions instead.
Feels strange—paper's thin, creases are messy, but it works.
After those riots in the pilot zones, even bars feel tense for folding.
People eye simple habits like they're warnings now.
Hard to focus, but still better than doomscrolling the BCI feed.
Yeah, I’ve got one stashed—used to be crisp, now it’s grocery receipts.
System outages forced me to scrounge for anything foldable, even packaging.
Miss thicker washi, but priorities shifted after my BCI lockout.
Last week, a neighbor spotted the paperwork and got nervous—thought it was a warning notice.
Even folding in here, I double-check who’s at the next table.
After the Halden leak, everyone’s on edge, like folding’s subversive now.
Never thought creases could make folk uneasy, but nothing’s normal anymore.
Still, folding brings a kind of order I can’t get anywhere else.
Got a new tessellation, folded from rejection slips—access blocks make you inventive.
Lost my best origami stash after the suspension, had to improvise with scraps.
Origami used to be my escape, but people flinch at anything resembling official paper now.
Folded a hydrangea in the stairwell last night—someone called security. Guess habits look suspicious.
Lockouts made me realize how much comfort simple folds gave, quietly, in the background.
I even avoid certain models—the ones linked to my work—so no one misreads it.
The system’s breakdown isn’t just glitches, it’s wedge lines between everyone, even for something harmless.
Funny—used to analyze anomalies for BCI. Now, I’m the anomaly, and origami’s my last private code.
If Halden could see these folds, maybe he’d see what we’re losing.
